newsitem.title: USA: Prudential filed $1 mln over document destruction.
newsitem.headline: Prudential filed $1 mln over document destruction.

text.p: The judge presiding over a policyholders' class-action suit against Prudential Insurance Co of America today fined the insurance giant $1 million for its role in destroying documents relevant to the case.

U.S. District Judge Alfred Wolin ordered the Newark-based insurer to prepare a plan to uncover any further document shredding and to prevent future misconduct. He also ordered Prudential to pay attorneys for the class-action plaintiffs for their time in making their charges of evidence tampering.

The suit charges Prudential with encouraging its sales agents to persuade policyholders to take out new, higher coverage -- paying the cost by cashing in existing policies -- without disclosing the full costs involved. The practice is called "churning" and has led to other suits against other insurers.

But the Prudential suit involves as many as 10.7 million policyholders, and the company has agreed to pay a minimum of $410 million. A settlement could cost the mutual insurer more than $1 billion, analysts say.

Prudential lawyers admitted to Judge Wolin that documents were destroyed in a Cambridge, Mass., office. The judge also found cause for action in sales offices in Des Moines, Iowa; Jacksonville, Fla., and Syracuse, N.Y.
He gave Prudential 30 days to file its response.
